turns.speaker: BLONDE
turns.text: They're yours.

turns.speaker: GRANDFATHER
turns.text: They are?

turns.speaker: BLONDE
turns.text: The cards... you're bank.

turns.speaker: BOY
turns.text: Here, mate, that's my hoop, stop playing with it.

turns.speaker: RINGO
turns.text: Hoop, this isn't a hoop, it's a lethal weapon. Have you got a licence for it?

turns.speaker: BOY
turns.text: Oh don't be so stroppy!

turns.speaker: RINGO
turns.text: Well! A boy of your age bowling <U>"hoop"</U> at people. How old are you anyway?

turns.speaker: BOY
turns.text: Nine.

turns.speaker: RINGO
turns.text: Bet you're only eight and a half.

turns.speaker: BOY
turns.text: Eight and two thirds.

turns.speaker: RINGO
turns.text: Well, there you are and watch it with that hoop.

turns.speaker: BOY
turns.text: Gerron out of it, you're only jealous 'cause you're old.

turns.speaker: RINGO
turns.text: Shurrup!

turns.speaker: BOY
turns.text: I bet you're  -- sixteen!

turns.speaker: RINGO
turns.text: Fifteen and two thirds, actually.

turns.speaker: BOY
turns.text: Well --

turns.speaker: RINGO
turns.text: All right, take your hoop and bowl.

turns.speaker: BOY
turns.text: Oh you can have it, I'm packing it in -- it depresses me.

turns.speaker: RINGO
turns.text: Y'what?

turns.speaker: BOY
turns.text: You heard, it gets on my wick.

turns.speaker: RINGO
turns.text: Well that's lovely talk, that is. And another thing, why aren't you at school?

turns.speaker: BOY
turns.text: I'm a deserter.

turns.speaker: RINGO
turns.text: Are you now?

turns.speaker: BOY
turns.text: Yeah, I've blown school out.

turns.speaker: RINGO
turns.text: Just you?

turns.speaker: BOY
turns.text: No, Ginger, Eddy Fallon and Ding Dong.

turns.speaker: RINGO
turns.text: Ding Dong? Oh Ding Dong Bell, eh?

turns.speaker: BOY
turns.text: Yeah, that's right, they was supposed to come with us but they chickened.

turns.speaker: RINGO
turns.text: Yeah? And they're your mates are they?

turns.speaker: BOY
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: RINGO
turns.text: Not much cop without 'em, is it?

turns.speaker: BOY
turns.text: Oh, it's all right.

turns.speaker: RINGO
turns.text: Yeah?

turns.speaker: BOY
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: RINGO
turns.text: What they like?

turns.speaker: BOY
turns.text: Ginger's mad, he says things all the time and Eddy's good at punching and spitting.

turns.speaker: RINGO
turns.text: How about Ding Dong?

turns.speaker: BOY
turns.text: He's a big head and he fancies himself with it but you know it's all right 'cos he's one of the gang.

turns.speaker: BOY
turns.text: Why aren't you at work?

turns.speaker: RINGO
turns.text: I'm a deserter, too.

turns.speaker: BOY
turns.text: Oh.

turns.speaker: GRANDFATHER
turns.text: What about all these letters?

turns.speaker: BOYS
turns.text: Read 'em!

turns.speaker: BOYS
turns.text: Shurrup!

turns.speaker: GRANDFATHER
turns.text: Isn't it always the way? Picking on us little fellas.

turns.speaker: GRANDFATHER
turns.text: Can you fix him for me?

turns.speaker: BOYS
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: GRANDFATHER
turns.text: Sixpence.

turns.speaker: GRANDFATHER
turns.text: The police have the poor unfortunate lad in the Bridewell.

turns.speaker: BOYS
turns.text: The police station.

turns.speaker: GRANDFATHER
turns.text: He'll be pulp by now.

turns.speaker: NORM
turns.text: All right, all right. If you don't need this lot, I'll lock 'em up in the dressing room till you do.

turns.speaker: DIRECTOR
turns.text: Please do, I'll not need them for fifteen minutes. Thank you.

turns.speaker: NORM
turns.text: Sure.

turns.speaker: DIRECTOR
turns.text: And hurry, they're not looking too happy.

turns.speaker: DIRECTOR
turns.text: Well, that's it, two minutes to the final run-through... they're bound to miss it...

turns.speaker: NORM
turns.text: I'll murder that Lennon.

turns.speaker: DIRECTOR
turns.text: But I suppose we can survive a missed run-through as long...

turns.speaker: DIRECTOR
turns.text: You don't think...

turns.speaker: NORM
turns.text: They'll be here.

turns.speaker: DIRECTOR
turns.text: Oh now, they can't do that to me.  It's all your fault.  Oh yes it is and if they don't turn up I wouldn't be in your shoes for all the...

turns.speaker: DIRECTOR
turns.text: Boys, you don't know what this means to me. If you hadn't come back it would have been the epilogue or the news in Welsh for life.

turns.speaker: NORM
turns.text: Aren't you supposed to be in that box?

turns.speaker: RINGO
turns.text: Leave them drums alone.

turns.speaker: FLOOR MANAGER
turns.text: Oh, surely one can have a tiny touch.

turns.speaker: RINGO
turns.text: If you so much as breathe heavy on them, I'm out on strike.

turns.speaker: FLOOR MANAGER
turns.text: Aren't you being rather arbitrary?

turns.speaker: RINGO
turns.text: That's right retreat behind a smoke screen of bourgeois cliches. I don't go round messing about with your ear-phones, do I?

turns.speaker: FLOOR MANAGER
turns.text: Spoil sport!

turns.speaker: RINGO
turns.text: Well!

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Would you like to be a little more precise, sir?

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Well, that's the wrong line for a start.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Sorry?

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Yeah, you know, "O.K. Buster, follow that car, there's a sawbuck in it for you if you get real close!"

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Oh, yes, now I'm with you. [he changes his accent] But, gee, Mister, I've got my license to think of ... we're doing a hundred now ...

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Ever seen one of these before?

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Ah ... a shamus, eh?

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: I see you go to the night court.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: I've made the scene.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Well, remember, its Leathery Magee up ahead in that convertible, so cover me in the stake-out.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: We're nearly there, sir.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Eh ... don't call him sir, he's got enough delusions of power as it is.

turns.speaker: RINGO
turns.text: He doesn't like me, honest, I can tell ... It's 'cos I'm little.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: You've got an inferiority complex, you have.

turns.speaker: RINGO
turns.text: Yeah, I know, that's why I took up the drums. It's me active compensatory factor.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Are you going in?

turns.speaker: RINGO
turns.text: No, she'll only reject me in the end and I'll be frustrated.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: You never know, you might be lucky this time.

turns.speaker: RINGO
turns.text: No, I know the psychological pattern and it plays hell with me drum skins.

turns.speaker: RINGO
turns.text: Me? Why?

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Bag-snatcher.

turns.speaker: RINGO
turns.text: I don't snore.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: You do - repeatedly.

turns.speaker: RINGO
turns.text: Do I snore?

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Eh, Ringo, do you know what happened to me?

turns.speaker: RINGO
turns.text: No. I don't.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Look, I'm terribly sorry but I'm afraid there's been some sort of a misunderstanding.

turns.speaker: SIMON
turns.text: Oh, you can come off it with us. You don't have to do the old adenoidal glottal stop and carry on for our benefit.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: I'm afraid I don't understand.

turns.speaker: SIMON
turns.text: Oh, my God, he's a natural.

turns.speaker: SIMON
turns.text: We want you to give us your opinion on some clothes for teenagers.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Oh, by all means, I'd be quite prepared for that eventuality.

turns.speaker: SIMON
turns.text: Well, not your real opinion, naturally. It'll be written out and you'll learn it.  Can he read?

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Of course I can.

turns.speaker: SIMON
turns.text: I mean lines, ducky, can you handle lines?

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: I'll have a bash.

turns.speaker: SIMON
turns.text: Good. Hart, get him whatever it is they drink, a cokearama?

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Ta.

turns.speaker: SIMON
turns.text: Well, at least he's polite. Tony Show him the shirts, Adrian.

turns.speaker: SIMON
turns.text: Now, you'll like these. You really "dig" them. They're "fab" and all the other pimply hyperboles.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: I wouldn't be seen dead in them. They're dead grotty.

turns.speaker: SIMON
turns.text: Grotty?

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Yeah, grotesque.

turns.speaker: SIMON
turns.text: Make a note of that word and give it to Susan. I think it's rather touching really. Here's this kid trying to give me his utterly valueless opinion when I know for a fact within four weeks he'll be suffering from a violent inferiority complex and loss of status if he isn't wearing one of these nasty things. Of course they're grotty, you wretched nit, that's why they were designed, but that's what you'll want.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: But I won't.

turns.speaker: SIMON
turns.text: You can be replaced you know, chicky baby.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: I don't care.

turns.speaker: SIMON
turns.text: And that pose is out too, Sunny Jim. The new thing is to care passionately, and be right wing. Anyway, you won't meet Susan if you don't cooperate.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: And who's this Susan when she's at home?

turns.speaker: SIMON
turns.text: Only Susan Campey, our resident teenager. You'll have to love her. She's your symbol.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Oh, you mean that posh bird who gets everything wrong?

turns.speaker: SIMON
turns.text: I beg your pardon?

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Oh, yes, the lads frequently gather round the T.V. set to watch her for a giggle. Once we even all sat down and wrote these letters saying how gear she was and all that rubbish.

turns.speaker: SIMON
turns.text: She's a trend setter. It's her profession!

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: She's a drag. A well-known drag. We turn the sound down on her and say rude things.

turns.speaker: SIMON
turns.text: Get him out of here!!

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Have I said something amiss?

turns.speaker: SIMON
turns.text: Get him out of here. He's knocking the programme's image!!

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: That's not your Grandfather.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: It is, y'know.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: But your Grandfather lives in your house. I've seen him.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Oh, that's me other Grandfather, but this one's me Grandfather and all.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: You see, he was going to get married but she threw him over for a butcher.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: A butcher?

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Yeah, she was fickle.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Gerron.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: No, straight up.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Aye and we'll have to watch it and all.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: I suggest you just give him the photos and have done with it.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Aye, but don't rush. None of your five bar gate jumps and over sort of stuff.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Now what's that supposed to mean?

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: I don't really know, but it sounded distinguished, like, didn't it?

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Did you look in here?

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: No. I mean, it's probably a honeymoon couple or a company director or something.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Well, let's broaden our outlook.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Sure. .

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Ah well. Eh, look!

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: What's up?

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: He's sulking again.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Ringo!

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Wake up!

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Oh, listen to teacher's pet.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: You crawler.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Eh, I don't know if you realise it, but ...

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: We do.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Yes. Your grandfather's stirred him up.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: He hasn't.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Yes, he's filled his head with notions seemingly.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: The old mixer, come on we'll have to put him right.

turns.speaker: SECRETARY
turns.text: Oh, there you are!

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Oh, I'm sorry, I must have made a mistake.

turns.speaker: SECRETARY
turns.text: You haven't, you're just late.  Oh, yes, he's going to be very pleased with you.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Is he?

turns.speaker: SECRETARY
turns.text: Yes, you're quite a feather in the cap.  Hello, I've got one ... oh, I think so ... yes, he can talk ... Well ... I think you ought to see him.  Of course, right away.

turns.speaker: SECRETARY
turns.text: Well ... come on.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Sorry.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Oh, Paul, you can't have your own way!!!

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: If I let you have your own way, you little rascal, will you respect me?

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Come on, Auntie, you're winning.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Get in there, Paul, she's weakening.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: That must have cost you a fortune in stamps, Ringo.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: He comes from a large family.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Should I say it?

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Follow your impulse.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: I don't think that bit's right.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: What do you expect from an ad lib ... Raymond Chandler?

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: How'd you like a dirty great drum roll giving you a clout right in the middle of your solo?

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: You're getting out of hand. I don't know what's come over you today.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: It's happened at last, we've become a limited company.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: I'll look in here again.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: What are we waiting for?

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Come here.

turns.speaker: SHAKE
turns.text: Morning!  Who's that little old man?

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: It's Paul's grandfather.

turns.speaker: SHAKE
turns.text: Oh aye, but I thought ...

turns.speaker: SHAKE
turns.text: No, I didn't you did ...

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Well, what happened?

turns.speaker: SHAKE
turns.text: The old fella wanted these pictures and Norm said he couldn't have 'em, all I said was 'aw go on, be big about it.'

turns.speaker: SHAKE
turns.text: Hello, he's not talking to me. He's having a sulk.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Well, it must be catching. He's given it to the champ here.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Sorry.

turns.speaker: SHAKE
turns.text: Eh, there's only three of them.

turns.speaker: GIRL
turns.text: Oh!

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Well ... go 'head, do the next bit.

turns.speaker: GIRL
turns.text: Go away! You've spoilt it.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Oh, sorry I spoke.

turns.speaker: GIRL
turns.text: Are you supposed to be here?

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: I've got you worried, haven't I?

turns.speaker: GIRL
turns.text: I'm warning you, they'll be back in a minute.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: D'you know something, "They" don't worry me at all. Anyroad, I only fancy listening to you ... that's all but if it worries you ... well ...

turns.speaker: GIRL
turns.text: You're from Liverpool, aren't you?

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: How'd you guess?

turns.speaker: GIRL
turns.text: Oh, it's the way you talk.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Is it ... is it, really?

turns.speaker: GIRL
turns.text: Are you pulling my leg?

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Something like that.

turns.speaker: GIRL
turns.text: I see.  Do you like the play?

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Yeah ... I mean, sure, well, I took it at school but I only ever heard boys and masters saying those lines, like, sounds different on a girl.  Yeah, it's gear on a girl.

turns.speaker: GIRL
turns.text: Gear?

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Aye, the big hammer, smashing!

turns.speaker: GIRL
turns.text: Thank you.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Don't mench ... well, why don't you give us a few more lines, like?

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: You don't half slam the door in people's faces, do you? I mean, what about when you're playing the part, like, hundreds of people'll see you and ...

turns.speaker: GIRL
turns.text: I'm not ...

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Oh, you're the understudy, sort of thing?

turns.speaker: GIRL
turns.text: No.  I'm a walk-on in a fancy dress scene. I just felt like doing those lines.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Oh, I see. You are an actress though, aren't you?

turns.speaker: GIRL
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Aye, I knew you were.

turns.speaker: GIRL
turns.text: What's that mean?

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Well, the way you were spouting, like ....  "I don't believe you, sir..." and all that. Yeah, it was gear.

turns.speaker: GIRL
turns.text: The big hammer?

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Oh aye, a sledge.

turns.speaker: GIRL
turns.text: But the way you did it then sounded so phony.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: No ... I wouldn't say that ... just like an actress ... you know.

turns.speaker: GIRL
turns.text: But that's not like a real person at all.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Aye well, actresses aren't like real people, are they?

turns.speaker: GIRL
turns.text: They ought to be.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Oh, I don't know, anyroad up, they never are, are they?

turns.speaker: GIRL
turns.text: What are you?

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: I'm in a group ... well ... there are four of us, we play and sing.

turns.speaker: GIRL
turns.text: I bet you don't sound like real people.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: We do, you know. We sound like us having a ball. It's fab.

turns.speaker: GIRL
turns.text: Is it really fab or are you just saying that to convince yourself?

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: What of? Look, I wouldn't do it unless I was. I'm dead lucky 'cos I get paid for doing something I love doing.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: ... all this and a jam butty too!!

turns.speaker: GIRL
turns.text: I only enjoy acting for myself. I hate it when other people are let in.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Why? I mean, which are you, scared or selfish?

turns.speaker: GIRL
turns.text: Why selfish?

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Well, you've got to have people to taste your treacle toffee.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: No, hang on, I've not gone daft. You see, when I was little me mother let me make some treacle toffee one time in our back scullery. When I'd done she said to me, "Go and give some to the other kids." So, I said I would but I thought to meself, "She must think I'm soft." Anyroad, I was eating away there but I wanted somebody else to know how good it was so in the end I wound up giving it all away ... but I didn't mind, mind, 'cos I'd made the stuff in the first place. Well ... that's why you need other people... an audience ... to taste your treacle toffee, like. Eh ... does that sound as thickheaded to you as it does to me?

turns.speaker: GIRL
turns.text: Not really but I'm probably not a toffee maker. How would you do those lines of mine?

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Well, look at it this way, I mean, when you come right down to it, that girl, she's a bit of a scrubber, isn't she?

turns.speaker: GIRL
turns.text: Is she?

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Of course ... Look, if she was a Liverpool scrubber ...  Eh, fella, you want to try pulling the other one, it's got a full set of bells hanging off it ... Y'what? ... I know your sort, two cokes and a packet of cheese and onion crisps and suddenly it's love and we're stopping in an empty shop doorway. You're just after me body and y'can't have it ... so there!!

turns.speaker: GIRL
turns.text: And you honestly think that's what she meant?

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Oh, definitely, it sticks out a mile, she's trying to get him to marry her but he doesn't want ... well ... I don't reckon any fella's ever wanted to get married. But girls are like that, clever and cunning. You've got to laugh.

turns.speaker: GIRL
turns.text: Well, it's nice to know you think we're clever.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: And cunning.

turns.speaker: GIRL
turns.text: And what do you do about it?

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Me? Oh, I don't have the time, I'm always running about with the lads ... no, we don't have the time.

turns.speaker: GIRL
turns.text: Pity.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Aye, it is but as long as you get by, it's all right, you know ... bash on, happy valley's when they let you stop. Anyroad, I'd better get back.

turns.speaker: GIRL
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: See you.

turns.speaker: GIRL
turns.text: Of course.

turns.speaker: RINGO
turns.text: Ah.

turns.speaker: GRANDFATHER
turns.text: Quite right, invites to gambling dens full of easy money and fast women, chicken sandwiches and cornets of caviar, disgusting!

turns.speaker: GRANDFATHER
turns.text: Will you ever look at him, sitting there wid his hooter scraping away at that book!

turns.speaker: RINGO
turns.text: Well ... what's the matter with that?

turns.speaker: GRANDFATHER
turns.text: Have you no natural resources of your own? Have they even robbed you of that?

turns.speaker: RINGO
turns.text: You can learn from books.

turns.speaker: GRANDFATHER
turns.text: Can you now? Aah ... sheeps' heads! You learn more by getting out there and living.

turns.speaker: RINGO
turns.text: Out where?

turns.speaker: GRANDFATHER
turns.text: Any old where ... but not our little Richard ... oh no! When you're not thumping them pagan skins, you're tormenting your eyes wid that rubbish!

turns.speaker: RINGO
turns.text: Books are good!

turns.speaker: GRANDFATHER
turns.text: Parading's better!

turns.speaker: RINGO
turns.text: Parading?

turns.speaker: GRANDFATHER
turns.text: That's it, parading the streets ... trailing your coat ... bowling along ... living!

turns.speaker: RINGO
turns.text: Well, I <U>am</U> living, aren't I?

turns.speaker: GRANDFATHER
turns.text: You're living, are you? When was the last time you gave a girl a pink-edged daisy? When did you last embarrass a sheila wid your cool appraising stare?

turns.speaker: RINGO
turns.text: Eh ... you're a bit old for that sort of chat, aren't you?

turns.speaker: GRANDFATHER
turns.text: At least I've a backlog of memories, but all you've got is that book!

turns.speaker: RINGO
turns.text: Aaah ... stop picking on me... you're as bad as the rest of them.

turns.speaker: GRANDFATHER
turns.text: So you <U>are</U> a man after all.

turns.speaker: RINGO
turns.text: What's that mean?

turns.speaker: GRANDFATHER
turns.text: Do you think I haven't noticed ... do you think I wasn't aware of the drift? Oh ... you poor unfortunate scuff, they've driven you into books by their cruel, unnatural treatment, exploiting your good nature.

turns.speaker: RINGO
turns.text: Oh ... I dunno.

turns.speaker: GRANDFATHER
turns.text: And that lot's never happier than when they're jeering at you ... and where would they be without the steady support of your drum beat, I'd like to know.

turns.speaker: RINGO
turns.text: Yeah ... that's right.

turns.speaker: GRANDFATHER
turns.text: And what's it all come to in the end?

turns.speaker: RINGO
turns.text: Yeah ... what's in it for me?

turns.speaker: GRANDFATHER
turns.text: A book!

turns.speaker: RINGO
turns.text: Yeah ... a bloomin' book!

turns.speaker: GRANDFATHER
turns.text: When you could be out there betraying a rich American widow or sipping palm wine in Tahiti before you're too old like me. A fine neat and trim lad the class of you should be helping himself to life's goodies before the sands run out. Being an old age pensioner's a terrible drag on a man and every second you waste is bringing you nearer the Friday queue at the Post Office.

turns.speaker: RINGO
turns.text: Yeah ... funny really, 'cos I'd never thought of it but being middle-aged and old takes up most of your time, doesn't it?

turns.speaker: GRANDFATHER
turns.text: You're only right.

turns.speaker: RINGO
turns.text: I'm not wrong.

turns.speaker: GRANDFATHER
turns.text: Where are you off to?

turns.speaker: RINGO
turns.text: I'm going parading before it's too late!

turns.speaker: GRANDFATHER
turns.text: Ringo, me old scout, they grabbed yer leg for the iron too, did they?

turns.speaker: RINGO
turns.text: Well I'm not exactly a voluntary patient.

turns.speaker: GRANDFATHER
turns.text: Shush! Have they roughed you up yet?

turns.speaker: RINGO
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: GRANDFATHER
turns.text: Keep your voice down, this lot'll paste you, just for the exercise. Oh they're a desperate crew of drippings and they've fists like matured hams for pounding defenceless lads like you.

turns.speaker: RINGO
turns.text: Have they?

turns.speaker: GRANDFATHER
turns.text: That sergeant's a body-blow veteran if ever I measured one. One of us has got to escape. I'll get the boys. Hold on son, I'll be back for you.

turns.speaker: RINGO
turns.text: Me!

turns.speaker: GRANDFATHER
turns.text: And if they get you on the floor watch out for your brisket.

turns.speaker: RINGO
turns.text: Oh, they seem all right to me.

turns.speaker: GRANDFATHER
turns.text: That's what they want you to think. All coppers are villains.

turns.speaker: RINGO
turns.text: What are you doing?

turns.speaker: GRANDFATHER
turns.text: Lip reading.

turns.speaker: RINGO
turns.text: What are they saying?

turns.speaker: GRANDFATHER
turns.text: Nothing good.

turns.speaker: GRANDFATHER
turns.text: Well, you got me here so do your worst but I'll take one of you with me.  Oh, I know your game, get me in the tiled room and out come the rubber hoses but I'll defy you still.

turns.speaker: SERGEANT
turns.text: Is there a fire, then?

turns.speaker: GRANDFATHER
turns.text: You ugly, great brute you, you have sadism stamped all over your bloated British kisser.

turns.speaker: SERGEANT
turns.text: Eh?

turns.speaker: GRANDFATHER
turns.text: I'll go on a hunger strike. I know your caper. The kidney punch and the rabbit-clout. The third degree and the size twelve boot ankle-tap.

turns.speaker: SERGEANT
turns.text: What's he on about?

turns.speaker: GRANDFATHER
turns.text: I'm soldier of the Republic, you'll need the mahogany truncheon for this boyo. A nation once again.

turns.speaker: SERGEANT
turns.text: Get Lloyd George over there with that mechanic in the cloth cap while I sort this lot out.

turns.speaker: SERGEANT
turns.text: Would you two like a cup of tea?

turns.speaker: GRANDFATHER
turns.text: You see, sly villains.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Hello, Grandfather!

turns.speaker: GRANDFATHER
turns.text: Hello.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: He can talk then?

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: And we're looking after him, are we?

turns.speaker: GRANDFATHER
turns.text: I'll look after meself.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Come on let's get this coffee.

turns.speaker: GRANDFATHER
turns.text: Before you go, I think it's only fair to warn you about me Grandson ... don't let our Paul have his own way all the time, 'cos if you do he won't respect you!

turns.speaker: GRANDFATHER
turns.text: That's right; convict without trial ... Habeas corpus.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Every morning.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: That'll keep you busy.

turns.speaker: GRANDFATHER
turns.text: It's your nose, y'see. Fans are funny that way. Take a dislike to things. They'll pick on a nose...

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Stay where you are everybody this is a raid and we want him.

turns.speaker: GRANDFATHER
turns.text: Who are these ruffians?... I've never seen them before in my life! ...

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: You see.  You know your trouble -- you should have gone West to America. You'd have wound up a Senior Citizen of Boston. As it is you took the wrong turning and what happened, you're a lonely old man from Liverpool.

turns.speaker: GRANDFATHER
turns.text: But I'm clean.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Oh no, you're not. You've gone too far this time ... and who's paying for all this?

turns.speaker: GRANDFATHER
turns.text: It's all taken care of. It's down on our bill.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Oh, well that's all right.  What?

turns.speaker: GRANDFATHER
turns.text: And to think me own grandson would have let them put me behind bars!

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Don't dramatise.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: All right, how about Ringo? I mean ... he's very upset, you know ... and as far as your girlfriend, little Audrey's concerned, she's finished with men for the rest of her natural, and another thing ...

turns.speaker: GRANDFATHER
turns.text: A harmless bit of fun, aah, none of you have any sense of humour left these days.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Oh, it's all right for you but those two girls were scared to death! Honest, Grandad, why? I mean, why do you do these things?

turns.speaker: GRANDFATHER
turns.text: You're left-handed, aren't you, Paul?

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Yeah ... so what?

turns.speaker: GRANDFATHER
turns.text: Why do you always use your left hand?

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Well, don't be daft, I've got to.

turns.speaker: GRANDFATHER
turns.text: And I take a left-handed view of life, I've got to.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: With a trombone hooter like yours it'd be unnatural if you didn't.

turns.speaker: GRANDFATHER
turns.text: Don't mock the afflicted, Pauly.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Oh for Pete's sake, It's only a joke.

turns.speaker: GRANDFATHER
turns.text: Well, it may be a joke, but it's his nose. He can't help having a horrible great nose, it's the only one he's got. And his poor little head's trembling under the weight of it.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Anything to spare?

turns.speaker: GRANDFATHER
turns.text: We've just finished, Pauly. Hey George, write us your John Henry on this picture.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: And another thing, where's that old mixer?

turns.speaker: GRANDFATHER
turns.text: Here, Pauly.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: No, that's his other one.

turns.speaker: SHAKE
turns.text: That's all right then.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Clean though, isn't he?

turns.speaker: SHAKE
turns.text: Oh yes, he's clean all right.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Is that yours?

turns.speaker: SHAKE
turns.text: For Ringo.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Aye, he looks a right lurker.

turns.speaker: SHAKE
turns.text: You're undressed. Where are your clothes?

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Well, what are we waiting for?

turns.speaker: SHAKE
turns.text: Aye, come on, honest, that grandfather of yours is worse than any of you lot.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: What are you doing there?

turns.speaker: SHAKE
turns.text: Hiding.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: I think you're soft or something.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Eh ... pardon me for asking but who's that little old man?

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: What little old man?

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: That little old man.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Oh, that one. That's me Grandfather.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: How d'you reckon that one out?

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Well ... everyone's entitled to two, aren't they, and this is me other one.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Well we know that but what's he doing here?

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Well, me mother thought the trip 'ud do him good.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Aye and fond of fresh meat and all.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: No ... it was his sweetbreads. She was dead kinky for sweetbreads. Anyroad, me mother thought it'ud give him a change of scenery, like.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Oh, I see.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Eh, he's a nice old man, isn't he?

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Oh yeah, he's very clean, y'know.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Aye, that's what I'm afraid of!

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: He's got you worried, then?

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Him, he costs you a fortune in breach of promise cases. He's a villain and a right mixer as well.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Gie's a kiss!

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Shurrup! Look, Mister, we've paid for our seats too, you know.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Give 'em a pull.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Shall I?

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: I hope he fell off.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Don't be callous.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: We've broken out, oh, the blessed freedom of it all!  Eh, have you got a nail file, these handcuffs are killing me. I was framed. I was innocent.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Will you stop it! Sorry to disturb you, miss...

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Don't worry, son, we'll get you the best lawyer trading stamps can buy.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Oh, it's a laugh a line with Lennon.  Anyroad up ... It's all your fault.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Gaw, it's depressing in here, isn't it? Funny...  'cos they usually reckon dogs more than people in England, don't they? You'd expect something a little more palatial.  Come on. Let's have a little action. Let's do something, then.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Like what?

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Well, I've got me gob stopper.  Look, a genuine Stradivarius, hand tooled at Dagenham.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Let's go and muck in.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Aye, before anyone stops us.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: You won't interfere with the basic rugged concept of my personality, will you, girl?

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Eh, don't take out me lines.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Behave...

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Foreign devil ...
